title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is publicly acknowledged by NATO's Secretary General or through an official NATO communiqué. The invitation must be made in accordance with NATO's open-door policy and must be supported by a consensus of NATO member states. Any formal application by Ukraine to join NATO must also be submitted prior to the resolution date. The question will resolve as No if no such invitation is made by the specified date.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations or the European Union. The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the race and must include restrictions on trade or economic activity. The confirmation of the event must come from an official Formula 1 announcement or a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary races or exhibitions that do not form part of the official Formula 1 calendar do not count. If the race is canceled or rescheduled after being announced, this question will resolve as No.

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant changes are defined as those that either: 
1. Introduce new safety regulations that are stricter than existing standards; or 
2. Repeal or amend existing regulations in a way that decreases safety standards. 
The legislation must be formally recognized and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) and must have been signed into law by the President. Temporary measures or regulations that do not constitute formal legislation do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially implemented a unified nuclear waste management policy that is agreed upon by all member states. The policy must include standardized procedures for the storage, treatment, and disposal of nuclear waste, and must be legally binding across the EU. The implementation must be confirmed by an official announcement from the European Commission or a similar authoritative body. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will suffice. Any interim measures or proposals that do not constitute a fully unified policy will not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear and unambiguous evidence that the expansion of the FIFA World Cup to 48 teams has resulted in a significant increase in global soccer viewership. This will be determined based on the following criteria:

1. Viewership Metrics: A minimum increase of 20% in global television viewership numbers compared to the last World Cup held with 32 teams, as reported by FIFA or a reputable sports analytics organization.

2. Attendance Records: Increased attendance at matches in the tournament, with at least 10% higher average attendance per match compared to the previous World Cup.

3. Social Media Engagement: A measurable increase in social media engagement metrics (likes, shares, comments) related to the FIFA World Cup, with at least a 25% increase compared to the previous tournament.

4. Reports from Reputable Sources: Confirmation of this increase from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

In the absence of clear metrics, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is credible evidence indicating that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a significant reduction in global CO2 levels. Specifically, the following criteria must be met:

1. Global CO2 emissions must show a measurable decline, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the International Energy Agency, with a documented reduction of at least 1% compared to 2020 levels.

2. The reduction must be attributed to initiatives and actions taken by Microsoft under its carbon negative pledge, including but not limited to:
   - Investment in renewable energy projects.
   - Implementation of carbon capture technologies.
   - Enhancement of energy efficiency in its operations and supply chain.

3. The impact must be recognized by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and supported by scientific assessments or reports from independent environmental organizations.

4. Any temporary fluctuations in CO2 levels due to global events (e.g., pandemics, economic downturns) will be considered, but the overall trend must show a long-term reduction attributable to Microsoft's efforts.

If, by the resolution date, the evidence does not meet these criteria, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in quantum computing based on the following criteria: 1. India must have a significant number of quantum computing publications in top-tier journals, at least 100 papers published in journals with an impact factor above 5. 2. India must have developed and deployed at least two quantum computing technologies or systems that are acknowledged as world-class by international experts. 3. India must have established a prominent position in international quantum computing collaborations, having hosted or significantly contributed to at least three major international quantum computing conferences or workshops. 4. The recognition must come from a reputable organization or consortium in the field of quantum computing, such as the IEEE or the Quantum Economic Development Consortium (QED-C). This question resolves as No if these criteria are not met by the specified date.

title: Will a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development be achieved through the use of artificial intelligence by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major breakthrough in the development of COVID-19 vaccines is achieved through the use of artificial intelligence (AI). A "major breakthrough" is defined as: 1. The development of a COVID-19 vaccine that demonstrates a significant improvement in efficacy or safety compared to existing vaccines, as determined by peer-reviewed clinical trial data. 2. The vaccine must be authorized for emergency use or approved by a recognized health authority such as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the European Medicines Agency (EMA). 3. The role of AI must be clearly documented in the research and development process, including contributions to vaccine design, optimization, or data analysis. This question resolves as No if no such breakthrough is achieved by the specified date.

title: Will Australia launch its own sovereign satellite navigation system by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Australia has successfully launched and made operational its own sovereign satellite navigation system that is independent of foreign systems. The system must be capable of providing accurate positioning, navigation, and timing services across Australia and surrounding regions. The launch must be officially announced by the Australian government and confirmed by credible reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., ABC News Australia, The Guardian Australia, Sydney Morning Herald). The system must be fully operational and not in a trial phase. Any reliance on foreign satellites for functionality will disqualify the resolution as Yes.

title: Will machine learning algorithms surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, machine learning algorithms demonstrate superior accuracy compared to human experts in predicting consumer behavior, as measured by a statistically significant performance metric (e.g., AUC, F1 score) in a peer-reviewed study or a major industry report. The study or report must compare the predictions of machine learning models against a representative sample of human predictions made by qualified professionals in the field. The algorithms must be publicly available and have been tested on real-world consumer behavior data. In the event of multiple studies reporting conflicting results, the resolution will rely on the consensus of at least three reputable sources (e.g., academic journals, industry reports) confirming that machine learning models have indeed surpassed human accuracy in this domain.

title: Will the Democratic Party (US) implement a policy to significantly boost technology startups by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Democratic Party (US) has officially implemented a policy that significantly boosts technology startups. A policy will be considered significant if it meets at least one of the following criteria: 1. The introduction of a federal grant program specifically aimed at technology startups with a budget of at least $1 billion. 2. The implementation of tax incentives for technology startups that result in a minimum of 20% increase in funding for such companies. 3. The establishment of a federal initiative that provides substantial support services (e.g., mentorship, resources, training) to at least 1,000 new technology startups. The policy must be formally announced and documented through an official government source or a credible news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) to be recognized as implemented.

title: Will a landmark legal case involving quantum mechanics principles emerge before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a landmark legal case is adjudicated that prominently involves principles of quantum mechanics. A 'landmark legal case' is defined as one that sets a significant legal precedent, is widely reported in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and is recognized by legal scholars and practitioners as having substantial implications for the interpretation or application of quantum mechanics in law. The case must be concluded with a final ruling or decision from a court of law, and the legal principles involved must explicitly reference quantum mechanics. Cases that merely mention quantum mechanics without a substantive legal ruling will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified by at least 100 countries, including the five largest greenhouse gas emitters: China, the United States, the European Union, India, and Russia. The treaty must have legally binding commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and must be recognized by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The ratification must be confirmed through official government announcements or documented records from the UNFCCC. A treaty is considered significant if it aims for a global temperature rise limit of well below 2 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels and includes provisions for climate finance and technology transfer to developing nations. Any treaty that is merely an amendment or extension of an existing treaty will not count towards this resolution.

title: Will Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceed 50% by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector is reported to exceed 50%. The market share must be based on credible data from authoritative sources such as eMarketer, Statista, or reports from reputable financial news organizations (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal). The market share calculation should include all online retail sales globally and exclude any sales from physical stores or non-e-commerce channels. The resolution will also consider any official statements from Amazon regarding their market share, provided they are corroborated by independent market research.

title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion) is officially subject to a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. The investigation must be publicly announced and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must focus on significant ethical concerns such as privacy violations, data misuse, or anti-competitive practices. The investigation must not be a routine or minor inquiry but rather one that could have substantial implications for the company's operations or regulatory framework.

title: Will the United States lead the world in quantum computing technology development by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is recognized as the global leader in quantum computing technology development based on the following criteria: 1. The U.S. must have achieved a significant technological breakthrough in quantum computing that is acknowledged by the scientific community and reported in reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). 2. The U.S. must have a higher number of patents filed in quantum computing than any other country, as reported by a recognized intellectual property organization. 3. The U.S. must have the most advanced quantum computer in terms of qubit count and error rates, as verified by independent assessments from credible organizations like IBM, Google, or academic institutions. 4. The U.S. must have established itself as the primary hub for quantum computing research and development, attracting the majority of global investment in this area. If the U.S. is tied with another country in any of these criteria, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX's Starship has successfully completed at least one commercial spaceflight that includes paying passengers and is recognized as a commercial service. The flight must reach low Earth orbit (LEO) and return safely to Earth. The commercial nature of the flight must be confirmed by SpaceX through an official announcement, and at least three reputable news sources (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post) must report on the flight. Additionally, the flight must not be a test flight or demonstration flight but rather a service intended for commercial customers. If the flight is conducted but does not include paying passengers, the resolution will be No.

title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government before January 1, 2030. The invitation must be confirmed through an official NATO announcement and recognized by all NATO member states. Additionally, Ukraine must fulfill the necessary criteria for membership as defined by NATO, including political and military standards. In the event of a conditional invitation or a membership action plan, the question will resolve as No unless the full membership is granted before the resolution date. Any informal discussions or statements regarding potential membership do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially held in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by a recognized authority, such as the United Nations or the European Union. The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the event must be recognized by the Formula 1 organization. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by official announcements from Formula 1 and credible reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or special exemptions to sanctions for the event do not negate the resolution of this question.

title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease (defined as a disease caused by a pathogen that is not previously identified in humans) leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies specifically designed to contain and control the spread of that disease. The technologies must be officially recognized and validated by relevant health and safety authorities, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The resolution will also consider credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the development and deployment of such technologies. Technologies that are in experimental or trial phases do not count; they must be fully operational and implemented in response to the infectious disease.

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes nuclear safety standards. Significant alterations include, but are not limited to: 1) Changes to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's authority or operational procedures, 2) New safety standards that are stricter than the current regulations, 3) Introduction of new technologies or methodologies that enhance nuclear safety, or 4) Comprehensive reviews or amendments to existing safety standards that are recognized as substantial by credible organizations such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission or the Department of Energy. The legislation must be officially recorded and published in the Congressional Record. Temporary measures or resolutions that do not result in permanent changes to the law do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the integration of information technology in education significantly reduce the global digital divide by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence that the integration of information technology in education has significantly reduced the global digital divide, as defined by the following criteria: 

1. **Access to Technology**: At least a 50% increase in the number of students in low-income regions who have access to the internet and digital devices for educational purposes compared to 2020 levels.
2. **Educational Outcomes**: Improvement in educational outcomes, measured by standardized test scores, in low-income regions that have integrated technology into their education systems, with a minimum average score increase of 10% compared to 2020.
3. **Global Reports**: Confirmation from authoritative sources, such as UNESCO or the World Bank, indicating that the digital divide in education has narrowed significantly in at least 50% of the countries classified as developing nations.

The resolution will be based on reports published by these organizations and corroborated by credible news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) that analyze the impact of technology in education on the digital divide.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A 'significant increase' is defined as at least a 20% rise in average global viewership numbers compared to the last World Cup held with 32 teams in 2018. This data must be sourced from reputable sports viewership analytics organizations such as Nielsen or FIFA's official reports. Additionally, this increase must be recognized by at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) as a direct result of the expansion. Viewership during preliminary matches or other unrelated tournaments does not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be made through a formal announcement by the WHO and must specifically cite climate-related factors as the cause of the health emergency. Examples of such diseases may include heat-related illnesses, vector-borne diseases exacerbated by climate change, and respiratory diseases linked to air quality deterioration due to climate factors. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be documented in WHO publications or press releases. If the WHO declares a health emergency that is indirectly related to climate change but does not explicitly cite climate factors, this question will resolve as No.

title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in quantum computing based on the following criteria:

1. **Research Output**: India must be among the top three countries in the world in terms of the number of published research papers in leading quantum computing journals, as indexed by Scopus or Web of Science, for the year 2030.

2. **Technological Advancements**: India must have developed and demonstrated at least one quantum computer with a minimum of 50 qubits that is operational and accessible for research and commercial use.

3. **Government Initiatives**: The Indian government must have launched a national strategy for quantum technologies, with significant funding (at least $1 billion) allocated to quantum research and development.

4. **International Collaboration**: India must have established formal partnerships with at least two leading international institutions or companies in the field of quantum computing, resulting in joint research projects or initiatives.

5. **Recognition**: The recognition of India's status as a leader in quantum computing must be confirmed by at least three major reputable sources (e.g., IEEE, Nature, or other leading technology or scientific publications) that assess global leadership in quantum computing.

The resolution will be based on the cumulative evidence and consensus from these criteria, with no single criterion being sufficient on its own.

title: Will a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development be achieved through the use of artificial intelligence by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a COVID-19 vaccine has been developed that utilizes artificial intelligence in its design, development, or testing process, and is authorized for emergency use or fully approved by a recognized health authority such as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the European Medicines Agency (EMA). The vaccine must demonstrate significant efficacy in clinical trials, with at least a 50% reduction in symptomatic COVID-19 cases compared to a placebo. The use of AI must be a critical component of the development process, such as in predicting vaccine efficacy, optimizing formulations, or analyzing trial data. Reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) must corroborate the breakthrough.

title: Will Australia launch its own sovereign satellite navigation system by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Australia has successfully launched and made operational its own sovereign satellite navigation system that is independent of foreign systems. The system must be able to provide positioning, navigation, and timing services across Australia and its surrounding regions, with a minimum accuracy level comparable to that of existing global systems such as GPS. The launch and operational status must be confirmed by an official announcement from the Australian government or relevant space agency. The system must not be a trial or experimental system; it must be fully functional and available for public and commercial use. If the system is partially operational, the question will still resolve as Yes if it is intended for full deployment by the resolution date.

title: Will machine learning algorithms surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a peer-reviewed study or credible report demonstrates that machine learning algorithms achieve a higher accuracy rate than human experts in predicting consumer behavior across a significant dataset. The algorithms must be assessed in a real-world scenario, not just in controlled experiments. The accuracy must be measured and reported in a manner that is consistent with industry standards for predictive analytics, with at least a 5% improvement over human accuracy. The study or report must be published in a reputable journal or covered by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of such publications, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the Democratic Party (US) implement a policy to significantly boost technology startups by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Democratic Party (US) has officially implemented a policy or set of policies aimed at significantly boosting technology startups. Significant boost is defined as the introduction of legislation or a federal program that provides at least $1 billion in funding, tax incentives, or grants specifically targeted at technology startups. This must be confirmed through official government announcements, reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times), and must demonstrate clear intent and measurable outcomes for technology startups. If the policy is implemented in a limited capacity (e.g., only for certain regions or sectors), it will still count as Yes if there is a clear plan for nationwide applicability or expansion.

title: Will North Korea undergo a major legal reform by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, North Korea has implemented a major legal reform that includes significant changes to its legal code, judicial processes, or human rights policies. Major legal reform is defined as changes that affect the fundamental structure of the legal system, such as the abolition of the death penalty, introduction of fair trial standards, or significant amendments to the criminal code that enhance individual rights. The reform must be officially recognized by the North Korean government and reported by reputable international news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of such reports, credible confirmation from human rights organizations or legal experts will also suffice. Minor adjustments or cosmetic changes to existing laws do not qualify as major legal reform.

title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified by at least 100 countries, including at least 5 of the top 10 largest greenhouse gas emitters (as listed by the Global Carbon Project). The treaty must have legally binding commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and must be recognized as a major treaty by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The ratification must be confirmed through official government announcements or documentation from the UNFCCC. If a treaty is ratified but not recognized by the UNFCCC or lacks binding commitments, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceed 50% by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceeds 50% as reported by authoritative market research firms such as eMarketer, Statista, or similar reputable sources. The market share must be calculated based on total e-commerce sales worldwide, including all categories of products sold online. The resolution will be based on the most recent and credible data available at that time. Temporary fluctuations or projections will not count; only confirmed data from reputable sources will determine the outcome.

title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $50 billion) is subjected to a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A 'landmark ethics investigation' is defined as an official inquiry initiated by a federal agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or the Department of Justice (DOJ), that addresses significant ethical concerns regarding the company's business practices, including but not limited to issues of data privacy, misinformation, or anti-competitive behavior. The investigation must be publicly announced and reported by at least two reputable news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.). If the investigation is subsequently dropped or dismissed without any findings, it will still count as a Yes for the purposes of this resolution.

title: Will the United States lead the world in quantum computing technology development by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is recognized as the global leader in quantum computing technology development. This recognition can be established through one or more of the following criteria: 

1. **Publications and Patents**: The United States has the highest number of significant peer-reviewed publications and patents in quantum computing compared to other countries, as reported by reputable sources such as the IEEE, Nature, or major academic institutions. 

2. **Investment and Funding**: The United States has the largest amount of public and private investment in quantum computing technology development, as reported by credible financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Wall Street Journal). 

3. **Commercialization**: At least three major quantum computing companies based in the United States have successfully developed and commercialized quantum computing products or services that are widely adopted in the industry. 

4. **International Consensus**: A consensus from leading international organizations or expert panels, such as the Quantum Economic Development Consortium (QED-C) or the National Quantum Initiative Advisory Committee, indicating that the United States is leading in quantum technology development. 

In the absence of clear consensus, if at least two of the above criteria are met, the question will resolve as Yes. Otherwise, it will resolve as No.

title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear and sustained evidence that the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines has led to permanent changes in workplace dynamics across major industries. This includes, but is not limited to, the following criteria:

1. **Remote Work Policies**: A significant percentage of companies (at least 50%) implement permanent remote or hybrid work policies as a direct result of changes initiated during the pandemic.

2. **Health and Safety Protocols**: Permanent changes to workplace health and safety protocols, including regular health screenings or vaccination requirements, are adopted by at least 50% of companies.

3. **Employee Well-being Programs**: An increase in employee well-being programs (such as mental health support, flexible working hours, etc.) is adopted by at least 50% of companies as a direct response to the pandemic.

The changes must be documented and reported by credible sources, including industry reports or major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) to confirm the adoption of these changes. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will a major breakthrough in pharmacology create a billion-dollar industry by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a breakthrough in pharmacology leads to the creation of a new industry with annual revenues exceeding one billion dollars. A 'major breakthrough' is defined as a novel drug or treatment that demonstrates significant efficacy in clinical trials and receives regulatory approval from a major health authority, such as the FDA or EMA. The industry must be recognized as distinct and separate from existing pharmaceutical markets. Evidence of the industry's financial success must be confirmed through credible financial reports, industry analysis, or news articles from reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If the industry achieves billion-dollar status but is subsequently merged or acquired by another company, it will still count towards resolution.

title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX's Starship has successfully completed a commercial spaceflight that includes at least one paying passenger traveling to low Earth orbit (LEO) or beyond. The flight must be conducted under a regulatory framework approved by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) or equivalent authority, and must be publicly reported by SpaceX or confirmed by credible news sources (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.). Additionally, the flight must demonstrate the capability for future commercial operations, meaning it should be part of a planned series of commercial flights, rather than a one-off event. If the Starship is used for government or non-commercial purposes, this does not count towards the resolution.

title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is formally invited to join NATO and the invitation is publicly acknowledged by NATO's official channels. The resolution will also consider any official accession of Ukraine to NATO that occurs prior to this date. The invitation must be supported by the consensus of NATO member states, as defined by Article 10 of the North Atlantic Treaty. Any interim agreements or partnerships that do not result in full NATO membership by the specified date will not count towards a Yes resolution.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions recognized by the United Nations or another authoritative body. The sanctions must be in place at the time of the event announcement. The event must be confirmed by Formula 1 management and reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or special exemptions for specific events do not count towards this resolution. If the Grand Prix is canceled or rescheduled to a different country before the event date, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly amends or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant amendments are defined as those that introduce new safety protocols, enhance existing ones, or change the regulatory framework governing nuclear facilities. The legislation must be officially documented and available in the Congressional Record, and it must have received bipartisan support, defined as at least 20% of the minority party voting in favor. Any temporary measures or resolutions that do not result in permanent changes to safety standards will not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially adopted a unified nuclear waste management policy that is legally binding for all member states. The policy must include comprehensive guidelines for the safe storage, transportation, and disposal of nuclear waste, and must be ratified by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union. The resolution will also consider any policy that has been agreed upon and is in the process of being implemented, provided that it has the support of at least 20 of the 27 EU member states. The policy must be publicly documented and available through official EU channels. Any temporary measures or national policies that do not align with a unified EU approach will not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the integration of information technology in education significantly reduce the global digital divide by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence that the integration of information technology in education has significantly reduced the global digital divide. This will be assessed through the following criteria: 

1. **Access to Technology**: A measurable increase in access to digital devices and internet connectivity in underserved regions, reported by reputable organizations such as UNESCO or the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).
2. **Educational Outcomes**: Demonstrable improvements in educational outcomes (e.g., literacy rates, graduation rates) in regions that have integrated information technology into education, as reported by credible educational assessments or studies published in peer-reviewed journals.
3. **Equity in Education**: Evidence that the gap in educational attainment between different socio-economic groups has narrowed, supported by data from recognized educational research institutions.

The resolution will rely on reports from at least two major international organizations (e.g., World Bank, UNESCO) that confirm these improvements. If there is significant debate or conflicting evidence regarding the impact, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a verifiable increase in global soccer viewership attributable to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. This increase must be quantified as a minimum of 20% compared to the average global viewership of the previous World Cup held in 2022, as reported by FIFA or confirmed by reputable sports analytics firms (e.g., Nielsen Sports, Statista). Viewership figures must be based on television and streaming data that are publicly available and credible. Any reports must be corroborated by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, ESPN, New York Times). If the increase is due to factors unrelated to the expansion (e.g., the popularity of specific teams or players), it will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria:

1. **International Recognition**: South Korea must be acknowledged as a leader in digital governance by at least three major international organizations, such as the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), or the World Economic Forum.

2. **Implementation of Standards**: South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance frameworks that are adopted by other countries, demonstrating effective practices in areas such as data protection, cybersecurity, and digital economy.

3. **Influence on Global Policies**: South Korea must play a significant role in shaping global digital policies or regulations, evidenced by hosting or leading international conferences, summits, or working groups focused on digital governance.

4. **Technological Innovation**: South Korea must be at the forefront of technological innovations that impact digital governance, such as advancements in artificial intelligence, blockchain technology, or cybersecurity measures, with these innovations being recognized globally.

The resolution will be based on reports and analyses from reputable sources, including major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and assessments from recognized international bodies.

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Microsoft's carbon negative pledge leads to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The reduction must be significant, defined as a decrease of at least 0.5% in global CO2 emissions compared to the levels reported in 2020. The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives, including but not limited to carbon offset projects, renewable energy investments, and operational changes that contribute to carbon negativity. The resolution will be based on comprehensive reports from credible environmental organizations and peer-reviewed studies that validate the claims of reduced CO2 levels directly linked to Microsoft's efforts.

title: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, a breakthrough in physics leads to the development of a new form of clean energy that meets the following criteria: 1. The new energy source must be capable of producing electricity or power at a scale that is commercially viable and can be integrated into existing energy infrastructure. 2. The energy source must have a significantly lower environmental impact compared to current fossil fuel sources, as defined by a reduction in carbon emissions and other pollutants. 3. The breakthrough must be recognized and validated by a consensus of the scientific community, including publication in a peer-reviewed journal and acknowledgment by at least three major energy or science organizations (such as the American Physical Society, the International Energy Agency, or equivalent). 4. The new energy form should be demonstrated in a practical application, such as a working prototype or pilot project, that is operational and not merely theoretical. In the absence of such a breakthrough, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically due to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be documented in an official WHO statement or report. Diseases considered for this resolution include, but are not limited to, vector-borne diseases (such as malaria and dengue), respiratory diseases exacerbated by air pollution, and heat-related illnesses. The declaration must indicate a significant increase in morbidity or mortality rates directly linked to climate-related factors. The resolution will not consider declarations related to natural disasters or other non-climate-related health emergencies.

title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in quantum computing by at least three of the following authoritative sources: the International Quantum Computing Association, the IEEE Quantum Initiative, or the World Economic Forum. The criteria for being a 'global leader' include: 
1. India must have at least one quantum computing platform that is widely adopted and utilized by industry and academia on a global scale. 
2. India must lead in the number of published research papers in top-tier quantum computing journals, surpassing other countries in terms of volume and impact. 
3. India must have established significant partnerships with leading global technology firms or academic institutions in quantum computing. 
4. India must host or co-host international quantum computing conferences or summits recognized by the global scientific community. 
The resolution will be based on the consensus of the aforementioned sources or credible reports from major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) that confirm India's position as a leader in this field.

title: Will Australia launch its own sovereign satellite navigation system by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Australia has officially launched and made operational its own sovereign satellite navigation system that is independent of foreign systems. The system must be capable of providing accurate positioning, navigation, and timing services to users across Australia and its territories. The launch must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation from the Australian Space Agency. The system must be fully operational and not merely in a testing or trial phase. In the case of a partial deployment, the question will resolve as Yes if the system is intended for nationwide coverage and is confirmed to be functioning as designed. Temporary or experimental systems do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the integration of cricket analytics technology significantly influence team strategies in major leagues by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is clear evidence that cricket analytics technology has significantly influenced team strategies in major leagues, defined as the Indian Premier League (IPL), Big Bash League (BBL), and the English County Championship. This influence must be demonstrable through: 1. Publicly available data showing a measurable change in team performance metrics (e.g., win rates, player performance statistics) linked to the use of analytics technology. 2. Official statements from at least three major teams in these leagues indicating that their strategies have been adapted based on insights gained from analytics technology. 3. Coverage by reputable sports news sources (e.g., ESPN, BBC Sport, The Guardian) discussing the impact of analytics on team strategies. In the absence of such evidence, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will North Korea undergo a major legal reform by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, North Korea has implemented significant legal reforms that are publicly announced and recognized by credible international organizations or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). Significant legal reforms are defined as changes to the legal system that enhance civil liberties, improve the judicial process, or establish new laws that align with international human rights standards. The reforms must be substantial and not merely cosmetic changes or minor amendments to existing laws. The resolution will be based on official government announcements or reports from at least two reputable international human rights organizations, such as Human Rights Watch or Amnesty International.

title: Will Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceed 50% by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector is officially reported to exceed 50%. Market share data must be sourced from reputable market research firms such as eMarketer, Statista, or similar authoritative sources. The market share must be based on total e-commerce sales, including both retail and digital services, and must be confirmed by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) reporting on the data. In the case of conflicting reports, the highest reported market share will be considered. If Amazon's market share is reported at exactly 50%, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a publicly traded company with a market capitalization exceeding $10 billion) is officially announced to be under a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. This investigation must be initiated by a federal agency such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The investigation must focus on significant ethical concerns, such as privacy violations, antitrust issues, or data misuse, and must be reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for the resolution to be considered valid. Temporary inquiries or minor investigations do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence that the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines has resulted in permanent changes in workplace dynamics across a significant number of organizations (defined as at least 25% of employers in a given industry or sector). Permanent changes may include but are not limited to: 
- Increased remote work policies that are adopted as standard practice rather than temporary measures. 
- Changes in employee health and safety protocols that are maintained post-pandemic. 
- Significant shifts in employee benefits related to health and wellness that have been instituted as a direct response to the pandemic. 
- Long-term alterations in workplace culture or employee engagement strategies that are directly linked to the pandemic response. 
The evidence for these changes must be documented through reputable sources, including reports from recognized industry associations, academic studies, or major news outlets (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.). Temporary changes or adaptations that revert back to pre-pandemic norms will not count towards this resolution.

title: Will a major breakthrough in pharmacology create a billion-dollar industry by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major breakthrough in pharmacology results in the creation of a new industry generating at least one billion dollars in annual revenue. A 'major breakthrough' is defined as the successful development and commercialization of a novel drug or treatment that is approved by a recognized regulatory authority (e.g., FDA, EMA) and addresses a significant medical need. The industry must be independently verified by credible financial reports or market analysis from reputable sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, or major financial publications) to confirm the billion-dollar revenue mark. In the case that multiple breakthroughs occur, the resolution will be based on the first to achieve the billion-dollar threshold.

title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX's Starship has successfully completed at least one commercial spaceflight that carries private paying passengers to low Earth orbit (LEO) or beyond. The flight must be conducted under the auspices of a recognized regulatory body, such as the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in the United States, and must include a formal announcement from SpaceX regarding the commercial nature of the flight. The flight must demonstrate the capability to safely transport passengers, including a full launch and successful return to Earth. Any flights that are purely experimental, governmental, or for non-paying passengers do not count towards this resolution. Additionally, the flight must be widely reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) to confirm its commercial status.
